private_information: I am a truck
Driving between any two places takes 10 time units
While driving I am not at any place (cannot satisfy over-all co-location requirements)
truck0.goal: Help move crates by transporting between places as needed to achieve final crate placements.

private_information: I am a truck
Driving between any two places takes 10 time units
While driving I am not at any place (cannot satisfy over-all co-location requirements)
truck1.goal: Help move crates by transporting between places as needed to achieve final crate placements.

private_information: I am a hoist
Lifting a crate from a surface takes 1 time unit (start effects happen at start)
Putting a hoist-held crate down on a surface takes 1 time unit (effects at end)
Putting a hoist-held crate into a truck takes 3 time units (effects at end)
Taking a crate out of a truck takes 4 time units (start effects happen at start)
Hoists remain at their place for actions that require over-all co-location
hoist0.goal: Assist in picking, placing, loading and unloading crates to achieve final crate placements.

orchestrator.goal: Coordinate trucks and hoists to achieve the global crate placement goals while respecting temporal and co-location constraints and minimizing total time.

public_information: Only trucks move between places; trucks take 10 time units to drive between any two places
Hoists are stationary at their places and perform lifts, putdowns, loads and unloads with specified durations
Crates can be on pallets or on other crates; crates on top act as clear surfaces if nothing is on them
Plans must respect start, over-all, and end temporal qualifiers and co-location requirements

orchestrator.system_prompt: You are an expert with multi-agent temporal PDDL problems. You will be provided information about the environment and the capabilities and knowledge of the agents which interact in the environment. You always provide a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file that describes the planning problem. Enclose the pddl domain between <domain></domain> tags, and the pddl problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep the actions for different agents distinct, so that there is no confusion as to which agent performs which action. Respect temporal qualifiers (at start, over all, at end) and durations and ensure co-location constraints are enforced.
orchestrator.prompt:
Your name is orchestrator.
Initial information about the environment: {environment->init}.
Goal for the environment: {environment->goal}.
The public information is: {environment->public_information}.
truck0's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->truck0->private_information}.
truck1's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->truck1->private_information}.
hoist0's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->hoist0->private_information}.
hoist1's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->hoist1->private_information}.
hoist2's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->hoist2->private_information}.
hoist3's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->hoist3->private_information}.
hoist4's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->hoist4->private_information}.
hoist5's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->hoist5->private_information}.
Think step by step and provide a PDDL domain and problem that encapsulate the integrated temporal model, respecting the constraints of each agent (trucks and hoists). Ensure actions include durations and proper start/over-all/end annotations, and model drive, hoist-lift, hoist-putdown, hoist-load-truck, and hoist-unload-truck actions. Do not make assumptions beyond the given information. There is no need for anything else beyond producing the pddl files.
